Fast catalytic conversion of diethylene glycol to morpholine over thermally stable Zn promoted Cu-NiO/Al2O3 catalyst prepared via combustion approach Kaibin Zhou a Xiaodan Sun a Yaseen Muhammad a b Peng Hu a Yaochu Li a Zhangfa Tong a Zhenxia Zhao a ⁎ a School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Key Laboratory of Petrochemical Resource Processing and Process Intensification Technology, Guangxi University, Guangxi, 530004, PR China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Key Laboratory of Petrochemical Resource Processing and Process Intensification Technology Guangxi University Guangxi 530004 PR China b Institute of Chemical Sciences, University of Peshawar, Peshawar, 25120, KP, Pakistan Institute of Chemical Sciences University of Peshawar Peshawar KP 25120 Pakistan ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Highly active and thermally stable M-Cu-NiO/Al2O3 catalysts (M represents Al/La/Mg/Zn) were prepared by combustion method and applied in diethylene glycol (DEG) conversion to morpholine (Mp). Copper species preserved relatively small crystallite size (19 nm), high dispersion (40.3%) and high surface area (272 m2/g) in M-Cu-NiO/Al2O3 catalysts. High dispersion and intimate contact of copper with Al and La/Mg/Zn synergistically enhanced DEG conversion and Mp selectivity. Addition of promoter i.e. La, Mg, or Zn facilitated the formation of surface defects and isolated species to inhibit migration and aggregation of Cu moities during calcination as well as in high temperature DEG conversion reaction. Compared to other catalysts, Zn-Cu-NiO/Al2O3 combusted catalyst exhibited the highest DEG conversion of 99% (55% higher than impregnated catlayst) and Mp selectivity (95%), even at a high DEG space velocity of 0.8 mL g−1 h−1. Moreover, Zn-Cu-NiO/Al2O3 exhibited excellent thermal stability i.e. less than 2% decrease in initial DEG conversion after 80 h of reaction. The catalysts followed an overall activity order of: Zn-Cu-NiO/Al2O3 > Mg-Cu-NiO/Al2O3  >  La-Cu-NiO/Al2O3. The catalysts were characterized by XRD, BET surface area, SEM and XPS techniques. The present study, credited to its cost-effective nature, simplicity of operation and high efficiency, can be effectively applied for DEG conversion to Mp on industrial level. Keywords Zn-promoted Cu-NiO/Al2O3 catalyst Ethylene glycol-nitrate combustion High Cu dispersion Thermal stability High space velocity 1 Introduction Morpholine (Mp) as a typical heterocyclic compound has great industrial importance and a wide range of applications [1]. It can be functionalized as a kind of chemical intermediate in drug/pesticide discovery [2,3], and rubber and textile industries [4]. Besides these applications, Mp shows good biodegradability, which has attracted considerable interest in the field of catalysis and antioxidant applications [5,6]. Over the last two decades, a number of concise and inventive methods have been proposed to synthesize Mp and its derivatives [2], among which catalytic amination of vapor phase diethylene glycol (DEG) is the most widely practiced [7,8]. As this process is catalytic, development of novel catalyst and its structural design are the critical factors which can affect activity as well as selectivity of the process. In this connection, Cu(Ni)-based colloidal catalysts have gained considerable attention in amination of alcohol recently [9–12] attributed to their low cost and high resistance to poisoning. Cu and Ni based catalysts have been reported with superior selectivity towards CO bond cleavage than CC bonds via hydrogenolysis reaction [13,14]. However, some bi/ternary Cu-Ni based catalysts have been found to exhibit low activity and thermal stability due to poor dispersion of Cu/Ni species [15] and aggregation of Cu(Ni)O crystallites at high temperature for H2 production (>200 °C) [16,17]. Thus, in case of catalytic Mp synthesis, the dispersion of active species and thermal stability with high anti-sintering ability in catalysts [18,19] are crucial factors and hot research points which require considerable attention. Many attempts have been made to design new methods for catalyst synthesis with better dispersion of active species and enhanced thermal stability. Zhao et al. [15] and Avgouropoulos et al. [20] applied combustion approach for the synthesis of Ni-Al2O3 and CuO-CeO2 catalysts with a significantly smaller crystal size of Cu or Ni than that prepared by impregnation technique, which resulted in 10–15 % increased CO conversion. Similarly, the incorporation of an extra promoter can also enhance the dispersion of active species and thermal stability. Hu et al. [21] studied that addition of Mn to Cu/Al2O3 catalysts can give rise to high dispersion of Cu nanoparticles, a large number of surface defects and exceptional catalytic hydrogenation performance in dimethyl succinate to γ-butyrolactone with stability enduring up to 100 h. Papavasiliou et al. [22] reported that 0.05% of ZnO doped into CuO-CeO2 catalysts led to significantly smaller crystal size of CeO2 than parent catalyst, which increased CO conversion from 38 to 51% in steam reforming of methanol. Similarly, few reports based on the conversion of DEG to Mp over supported Ni and Cu based catalysts can be found (Table S1), most of which suffer either from low DEG conversion or Mp selectivity. Up to the authors’ knowledge, no reports on the incorporation of Al, La, Mg and Zn to Cu-NiO/Al2O3 used for the conversion of DEG to Mp can be found. Thus, in this work, a series of Cu-NiO/Al2O3 catalysts promoted by oxides of Al, La, Mg, and Zn were synthesized via combustion approach and tested in DEG conversion to Mp with high activity, thermal stability and selectivity. Rapid synthesis process and homogeneous mixing resulted in high dispersion of active species in catalytic samples. The physicochemical properties of catalysts were characterized by X-Ray diffraction (XRD), N2O titration experiments, N2 adsorption/desorption, hydrogen temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Furthermore, effects of preparation methods, Cu/Al ratio, and liquid hour space velocity (LHSV) on gas phase DEG conversion and Mp selectivity over promoter-loaded Cu-NiO/Al2O3 catalysts were systematically investigated. Thermal stability performance and durability test of the catalysts were investigated using temperature-swing reaction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and reagents Different metal nitrate salts i.e. (Cu(NO)2·3H2O, Ni(NO3)3 · 6H2O, Al(NO3)3 · 9H2O, La(NO3)3 · 6H2O, Zn(NO3)2 · 6H2O and Mg(NO3)2 · 6H2O, >99.0%, AR) were purchased from Guangdong Guanghua Sci-Tech Co. Ltd. Al2O3, Ethylene glycol (C2H6O2, ≥99.0%) and DEG (C4H10O3, ≥99.0%) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagents Co. Ltd. All other solvents and reagents were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The M-Cu-NiO/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared by combustion method [15]. Firstly, Cu(NO3)2 · 3H2O, Ni(NO3)2 · 6H2O and Al(NO3)3 · 9H2O were dissolved in deionized water with Cu:Ni:Al molar ratio of 5:1:x (x  =  0, 1, 4 and 10), and Cu, Ni, Al as 10, 1.8 and 0.84 wt.% of the support. The mixture was moderately stirred at 293 K till dissolution, to which 2 wt.% promoter specie (Mg, La, or Zn) was added using their respective nitrate precursors. 6 g pre-calcined Al2O3 (particle size of 180–325 μm) at 973 K, was added to this mixture followed by the addition of 5 mL ethylene glycol under constant stirring. The resulting mixture was kept in an ultrasound bath at 47 kHz with a power of 30 W for 1 h. The mixture was calcined in muffle furnace at 773 K for 5 h at a heating rate of 5 K/min. The obtained promoter based catalysts i.e. Mx-Cu-NiO/Al2O3, were denoted as Mx-Aly, where M represents promoter (Mg, La or Zn), x and y represent the ratio of promoter and Al respectively. All catalysts reported in this study contained a fixed amount of Cu-NiO/Al2O3 while combustion appraoch for catalyst synthesis is represented as CS. For comparison, unsupported Cu-NiO catalyst and Mx-Cu-NiO/Al2O3 were also prepared via impregnation method [23] and labeled as CS-Alx and IS-Al1-Zn (Table S2). Similar protocol was followed for IS-Al1-Zn as that of CS-Al1-Zn except the absence of ethylene glycol addition. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The morphology of synthesized catalysts (IS-Al1-Zn and CS-Alx-M) was analyzed by SEM (SEM, S-3400N, Hitachi), while crystal structure was characterized by XRD, which was collected on a conventional Rigaku Smartlab X-ray diffractometer, with a scan speed of 10°/min over 2θ ranging from 5 to 80°, using Cu Kα source (λ  =  1.5406 Å) radiation at 40 kV and 50 mA in air. The crystallite size was calculated from XRD patterns using Scherrer formula: d = kλ/βcosθ (k  =  0.89) [24]. Specific surface area was estimated from nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms at 77 K (BET) using a Micromeritics ASAP 2460 analyzer after degassing under vacuum at 200 °C for 3 h [25,26]. Surface metallic copper atoms were measured using AutoChem 2950HP (Micromeritics Instrument) via N2O oxidation followed by H2 titration as reported previously [27]. Catalysts were first reduced in 10% H2/N2 mixture with a flow rate of 30 mL/min at 450 °C. The amount of hydrogen consumed in this stage was denoted as x. Next, 2.54% N2O/N2 (30 mL/min) was switched to oxidize metallic copper atoms to Cu2O at 50 °C for 0.5 h. The reactor was flushed with He to remove oxidant gases. Finally, another TPR experiment was performed in 10% H2/N2, at 10 °C/min and a flow rate of 30 mL/min. Hydrogen consumption in the second TPR was denoted as y. The number of copper atoms on the surface was calculated assuming a molar stoichiometry of N2O/Cu  =  0.5 [28]. All CuO species were reduced to Cu in the first H2-TPR as: CuO + H 2 → Cu + H 2 O . The amount of H2 consumed in this step was defined as “x”. In the second TPR treatment, surface copper species that were oxidized to Cu2O by N2O at 50 °C, were reduced as: C u 2 O + H 2 → 2 Cu + H 2 O , and the H2 consumed in this step was denoted as “y”. Using x and y, the dispersion of Cu and exposed Cu surface area were calculated using Eqs. (1) and (2), respectively: (1) D = 2 y x × 100 % (2) S = 2 y N a v x M C u × 1.4 × 10 19 = 1353 y x m 2 -Cu/g-Cu where D and S represent Cu dispersion and Cu surface area (m2/g) respectively, N a v is Avogadro’s constant, M C u is relative atomic mass of Cu (63.456 g/mol), and 1.4  ×  1019 comes from equal abundance of an average copper surface atom area of 0.0711 nm2 (equivalent to 1.4  ×  1019 copper atoms m−2) [27]. TPR experiments were performed under a flow of 10% H2/Ar mixture (30 mL/min) over 150 mg of catalyst using a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Prior to TPR, the synthesized catalysts were treated at 350 °C for 30 min under pure Ar atmosphere. A thermal conductivity detector (TCD) was used for on-line monitoring of TPR effluent gas. XPS spectra were recorded with a Kratos Axis Ulra XPS system. The Al Kα X-ray (hν  =  1486 eV) was operated at 15 kV and 20 mA. The obtained binding energy (BE) of carbonaceous C 1s was referenced to 284.6 eV. XPS analysis was performed for catalysts already reduced at 300 °C in order to investigate the nature of Cu/CuO species on the surface. 2.4 Catalytic activity tests Catalytic activity in terms of DEG conversion and selectivity for Mp were carried out in a continuous-flow fixed-bed reactor as shown in Scheme S1. 2 g catalyst (particle size of 180–350 μm) was packed into the homemade stainless steel tubular reactor (inner diameter 10 mm, length 400 mm). Prior to the activity measurements, the fresh catalysts were reduced at 300 °C and atmospheric pressure for 1.5 h under a mixture of 20 vol.% H2 in N2. Then, the reactor was cooled down to 230 °C in N2 atmosphere and the liquid reactant was introduced under H2 atmosphere. The flow rate of H2 and liquid reactant were controlled by a mass flow controller and dual piston micro-pump, respectively. The pressure inside the reactor was controlled with a back-pressure regulator located on the exit of the reactor. The reactor temperature was controlled by a temperature control unit and measured with a chromel-alumel thermocouple. Each experiment was performed in triplicates and respective standard deviation was calculated for each set of data. Reaction products were collected at an interval of 2 h, diluted with methanol, and quantitatively analyzed using a gas chromatograph (GC) (Agilent GC7820A) with a flame ionization detector (FID) and a nonpolar HP-5 capillary column (5%-benzene methylpolysilicone, 30 m in length and 0.25 mm in inner diameter). Qualitative analyses for the products were performed using GC–MS chromatograph (Agilent 7890A-5975C) with a nonpolar HP-5MS capillary (5% phenyl-methylpolysiloxane) column, which was 30 m in length and 0.25 mm in inner diameter. Conversion and selectivity were calculated according to Eqs. (3)–(5). (3) X D E G ( % ) = C D E G − C D E G ' C D E G × 100 (4) S M p ( % ) = C M p C D E G − C D E G ' × 100 (5) Y M p ( % ) = S M p X D E G × 100 where XDEG is DEG conversion, C D E G and C D E G ' represent concentration of DEG before and after reaction, respectively; C M p is the concentration of Mp in collected product; S M p and Y M p represent Mp selectivity and yield, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts 3.1.1 SEM-EDS SEM images of CS-Al1-Zn, CS-Al1 and IS-Al1-Zn are shown in Fig. 1 (a1–c1). These images suggest a more uniform morphology with smaller particle size by the catalysts prepared via combustion solution method (CS-Al1-Zn and CS-Al1) than those prepared via impregnation method (IS-Al1-Zn). To confirm the dispersion of Cu/Ni species in the synthesized catalysts, energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mappings were performed as shown in Fig. 1(a2–c2 and a3–c3). Overlay of Cu and Al (Fig. 1a2–c2) as well as Cu and Ni (Fig. 1a3–c3) display that Cu species exhibited smaller particle size and well-dispersion within CS-Al1-Zn and CS-Al1 compared to IS-Al1-Zn. In Fig. 1, it can be seen that addition of Zn enhanced uniform dispersion of Cu species without any clots in CS-Al1-Zn, thus allowing intimate contact of Cu with Ni and Al oxides. Meanwhile, the well dispersed Ni and Al species can act as isolated island restraining the coagulation of catalyst particles and growth of crystal grain [29]. On the contrary, the dispersion of Cu/NiO was very low and aggregated in IS-Al1-Zn catalyst, which had a small contribution to catalytic activity at low reaction temperature (<230 °C) [30]. Fig. 2 shows the SEM images of CS-Al1 and CS-Al1-Zn catalysts before and after reaction at 290 °C. Both the catalysts exhibited porous appearance without agglomeration before reaction while CS-Al1-Zn exhibited higher porosity, large surface area and more uniform particles dispersion than CS-Al1. In the post reaction images, CS-Al1-Zn still maintained good porous structure, while that of CS-Al1 collapsed due to high temperature exposure. It is believed that the strong interaction between Cu species and ZnO [31] or CuO has an intimate contact with ZnO [32], which leads to higher thermal stability of Zn promoted catalysts. 3.1.2 X-Ray diffraction (XRD) Fig. 3 shows the XRD patterns of the pre-reduced catalysts. No peaks for Ni and its oxides were detected which might be due to their fine dispersion in the catalysts [33] and/or low crystallinity [34] (below the detection limit). XRD patterns of CS-Al0, CS-Al1, CS-Al4, CS-Al1-Mg, CS-Al1-La and CS-Al1-Zn were similar, where CuO and Al2O3 exhibited diffraction peaks at 2θ of 35.6/38.8° and 46/66°, respectively [13,15]. The diffraction peaks of CuO became weaker and broader with the addition of Al species demonstrating smaller crystallite size and decrease in degree of crystallinity. It may be attributed to the fact that Cu particles were dispersed and spatially isolated by Al species, and hence can avoid sintering. Also, the lower crystallinity of Cu species would cause the change in binding energy of Cu-O, which could alternatively affect the catalytic activity for Mp synthesis. Moreover, a decline in diffraction peaks of CuO to variable extents was noted by the addition of Mg, La and Zn at fixed dosage of Al. Among these catalysts, CuO in CS-Al1-Zn exhibited minimum intensity and broadest diffraction peaks showing the smallest crystallite size of the calcined species [35]. It is believed that Zn having similar atomic radius and chemical properties to Cu, can preferentially enter into CuO skeleton, creating Zn-Cu active sites on the Cu surface [36]. Moreover, Zn can enhance surface defects formation during sintering [37], and hence can hinder crystallization and growth of catalyst grains [38], which is evident by its prominent influence on CuO crystallinity (Table 1 ). Fig. 3b presents the XRD patterns of CS-Al1-Zn and IS-Al1-Zn, where the latter exhibited sharper peaks and larger crystallite sizes (Table 1) than the former, indicating higher degree of resulting sintering in the latter. Also, CuO crystallite size corresponding to the broadening of 111 line was determined from Scherrer formula: d = kλ/βcosθ, where k = 0.89, and λ = 1.5406 Å [39], and the data are provided in Table 1. As shown, the combustion method prompted the formation of small crystal size of CuO than common impregnation approach. After loading Al and other promoter species, its crystal size was further decreased, among which the effect of Zn2+ was significant i.e. 18 nm and 29 nm for CS-Al1-Zn and IS-Al1-Zn, respectively. In the combustion synthesis, the energy released from the exothermic reaction between the nitrates and the fuel can be ignited at a temperature much lower than the actual phase transformation temperature. The heat required to drive the chemical reaction and accomplish the compound synthesis, is provided in situ by the reaction rather by external source. Therefore, a fast phase transformation of active species at lower temperature limits the occurrence of agglomeration, thus leading to nano-crystalline powder in comparison to traditional impregnation approach [20]. Small crystal size of CuO species enabled their efficient reduction compared to bulk phase, and hence presented high activity and selectivity for Mp synthesis. 3.1.3 N2 adsorption and N2O titration Table 2 shows textural properties of the prepared catalysts, which suggest that C-Al10 exhibited lower surface area (20–30 m2/g) than Al2O3 support (108 m2/g). The surface area of CS-Al1 over Al2O3 was similar to bare Al2O3 with 14% increase in pore volume. Among the catalysts, CS-Al1-Zn possessed the highest surface area (124.2 m2/g) and pore volume (0.412 cm3/g), which could be attributed to the combustion step during catalyst synthesis. Furthermore, high dispersion of CuO/NiO/ZnO in CS-Al1-Zn catalysts can enhance the formation of new pores and concomitantly inhibit particle growth hence ultimately avoiding the blockage of pores on the support. To further investigate porous texture, N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of CS-Al0, CS-Al1, and CS-Al1-Zn catalysts are plotted as shown in Fig. 4 . All of the three isotherms are of the type IV, which is characteristic of mesoporous materials having pore size range of 2–50 nm [40]. In magnified isotherms in Fig. 4 (in-set), the shape of the hysteresis loop in each case was a superposition of H4 type, indicating the presence of narrow slit-like mesopores with uniform size and/or shape. The hysteresis loop was gradually shifted to lower relative pressures with less steep adsorption/desorption branches after Al/Zn doping. It can be seen in Table 2 that promoter (Mg, La and Zn) doping in CS-Al1-M led to decrease in pore size (below 12 nm) and increased surface area, which are conducive to maximize contact between NH3/DEG dehydration sites leading to enhanced Mp synthesis [41]. On the contrary, IS-Al1-Zn exhibited a dramatic decline in specific surface area and pore volume, which could be due to the blockage of some pores on Al2O3 surface by Cu-Ni oxide species. Other factors to the decreased surface area in IS-Al1-Zn could be low dispersion and obvious aggregation of the irregular particles. The role of Cu dispersion in catalytic activity is crucial and surface area of metallic Cu is a mirror of CuO dispersion which was determined by N2O [27]. Results in Table 2 show that IS-Al1-Zn catalyst had the lowest Cu specific surface area i.e. 5.0 m2/g which increased 7–11 folds after combustion, and was further increased by the addition of La, Mg and Zn. CS-Al1-Zn exhibited maximum Cu surface area (272.3 m2/g) and Cu dispersion (40.3%) among all samples. It was noted that combustion method and addition of Al and Zn synergistically enhanced Cu surface area by 54 times (in CS-Al1-Zn) than that of IS- Al1-Zn, which led to high dispersion of active species. 3.1.4 H2-TPR measurements H2-TPR measurements were performed to test the reduction behavior of catalysts as depicted in Fig. 5 . CS-Alx (x  =  0, 1 and 4) samples exhibited two overlapping reduction peaks at low temperature (α) and high temperature (β), ascribed to the reduction of copper ions in the form of dispersed CuO and bulk CuO species, respectively, which are less associated with alumina support [35]. From Fig. 5a it can be seen that CS-Al1 catalyst possessed highest temperature (143.7 °C) for α peak but the lowest temperature (199.1 °C) for β as compared to CS-Al0 and CS-Al4. Complete absence or presence of excessive Al2O3 enables the two peaks to move back and forth, while smaller crystal size and high dispersion of CuO can enhance its reduction, resulting in more peak overlap. Moreover, higher temperature for peak α signaled that CuO particles were in strong interaction with Al2O3 by forming a spinel CuAlO2 species [21]. Thus, CS-Al1 had smaller particle size distribution and higher dispersion of CuO than CS-Al0 and CS-Al4, and showed an intimate shoulder peak for CuO reduction [42]. Fig. 5b shows comparative H2 reduction profiles of combusted CS-Al1-Zn and impregnated IS-Al1-Zn catalysts. Both the catalysts had only one broad TPR peak, in which CS-Al1-Zn showed enhanced reducibility (peak shifted 40 °C to lower temperature), which suggests a diminished CuO crystallite size and uniform surface morphology, while TPR peak at higher temperatures in IS-Al1-Zn was due to bulk CuO [30]. TPR results further confirmed that combustion method for catalyst synthesis preferentially results in high dispersion of Cu species than impregnation approach. Moreover, no reduction peak of NiO appeared in the H2-TPR curves under the tested conditions, which was further confirmed by the absence of any bulk NiO crystal in the XRD patterns of CS-Al1-Zn (Fig. 3). The absence of NiO peak was attributed to finely dispersed NiO and low crystallinity, which resulted in no H2 consumption in TPR tests even above 300 °C [15,43]. Doping of Mg and La induced peak splitting of TPR spectra as visible in Fig. 5b. Therefore, their TPR data were quantified by means of peak-differentiation-imitating analysis in Fig. 5b and Table S3. As can be seen, compared to CS-Al1-Zn, Mg-doped sample showed a shoulder-peak in temperature range of 100–250 °C, which may be ascribed to the heterogeneous activity sites in CS-Al1-Mg. The lower shifting trend indicated a weaker correlation between crystal boundary of metallic Cu and support after Mg incorporation in comparison to Zn addition. This can be attributed to the inhibiting effect of Mg in migration and aggregation of isolated Cu species during reduction or reaction [44]. However, La doped Al/Cu/NiO catalyst significantly altered reduction temperatures having three temperature peaks (119, 181 and 224 °C) with corresponding peak area of 20, 44 and 36% of the total peak area (Table S3). It can be seen that some nanocrystal CuO in CS-Al1-La showed weak interaction with support, high concentration and aggregates of bulk Cu/CuO and poor dispersion of Cu, which could be due to inefficient resistance to Cu interfacial migration by La after high temperature calcination. 3.1.5 XPS measurements Cu 2p XPS results of CS-A catalysts with different Al contents are shown in Fig. 6 a where all samples show the satellite peaks of Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2. The peak of Cu 2p3/2 around 935 eV was attributed to CuO, accompanied by shakeup satellite peaks located at 942–946 eV belonging to Cu2+ species [45]. Cu 2p3/2 peak binding energies of CS-Al0, CS-Al1 and CS-Al4 exhibited no significant variations with increasing Al content. From these results along with the data of XRD and N2 adsorption, it can be deduced that Al addition may not effectively promote the dispersion of active components and their interaction with other species in the catalysts. Fig. 6b shows the Cu 2p XPS spectra of promoter doped CS-Al1 catalysts. Among the three promoters loaded catalysts, Mg- and Zn-loaded CS-Al1 slightly shifted all peaks to higher binding energy of Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2, demonstrating the enhancement in interaction between Cu species and support in CS-Al1 catalyst. On the contrary, CS-Al1-La improved the stability of catalysts by restraining sintering of Cu particles. These conclusions are consistent with the results of XRD and N2O titrations. 3.2 Catalytic performance 3.2.1 Effect of Al content on catalytic performance of CS catalysts Effect of Al amount in combusted catalysts on catalytic performance is shown in Fig. 7 . The selectivity of Mp shows gradual decrease with increasing Al amount while DEG conversion exhibited a volcano-shaped trend with respect to Cu/Al ratio. Maximum DEG conversion at Cu/Al  =  5:1 could be ascribed to better metal dispersion due to increased concentration of Al with high number of acidic sites, facilitating better catalyst-reactants contact and enhanced affinity towards NH3 [46]. As previously reported, Al species can efficiently create weak Lewis acidic sites on Cu-Al catalysts [12] and hence can enhance fruitful reactant-catalyst interaction. These results further show that Cu particles were surrounded and spatially isolated by an optimized amount of alumina, beyond which, Al could cover active sites of catalyst or precipitates on its surface, leading to decreased Mp yield. Similarly, an optimum number of active acidic sites in terms of Al species are required for better DEG conversion and high Mp selectivity, while further increasing Al contents could hinder and inhibit Mp selectivity. 3.2.2 Effect of space velocity on DEG conversion and Mp selectivity The effect of space velocity on DEG conversion and MP selectivity are shown in Fig. 8 . An inverse relation between these variables could be attributed to insufficient contacts between gaseous DEG/NH3 species with catalytic active sites at shorter reaction time (high space velocity) leading to decreased DEG conversion [47]. It is further noted that both DEG conversion and MP selectivity were affected to various degrees by varying space velocity. For instance, DEG conversion of CS-Al1-Zn combusted catalyst remained above 97% even at a high space velocity of 0.8 mL g−1 h−1, compared to CS-Al0 and impregnated IS-Al1-Zn with 64 and 61% conversion, respectively. This could be due to the absence of isolated species and Al acidic sites and presence of bulk Cu species in Cu/NiO@Al2O3 catalysts, which adversely affected DEG conversion [35]. On the contrary, comparatively mild influence i.e. <5% decline in Mp selectivity was observed by increasing space velocity from 0.3 to 0.8 mL g−1 h−1 (Fig. 8b), which could be due to the highest surface area and large dispersion of Cu species (Table 2) in these catalysts [48]. Furthermore, it is believed that space velocity affects DEG conversion to major extent, and Mp selectivity to minor extent credited to the fact that the former was controlled by reactant and active sites contacts, while the latter depended on its onward conversion to other products (Fig. 8b). On the other hand, combustion method facilitated better incorporation of Cu2+ ions onto support, and formed small Cu particles [49] than impregnation technique, which was confirmed by higher DEG conversion and Mp selectivity by the former. 3.2.3 Thermal stability tests Thermal stability of the prepared catalysts was investigated via temperature-swing reaction and results are compiled in Fig. S1. All samples show a significant decline in DEG conversion and Mp selectivity after suffering higher temperature reaction (290 °C) for 5 h. The biggest drop of DEG conversion (80% of original) and Mp selectivity were noted in CS-Al1. After doping La, Zn, and Mg, the decrease in DEG conversion and Mp selectivity mitigated distinctly. By contrast, CS-Al1-Zn shows a slight decrease in DEG conversion (from 99 to 98%) and Mp selectivity (from 95 to 93%) of the original at 230 °C, showing the thermally stable nature of the catalyst. Fig. 9 shows that DEG conversion increased slightly (from 97 to 99%) with reaction temperature (290 °C), however, it could not completely recover to the original level by dropping reaction temperature to 230 °C. The decrease in DEG conversion increased with reaction temperature in case of IS-Al1-Zn catalyst, suggesting its poor thermal stability for Mp synthesis. It could be attributed to the growth or aggregation of Cu/Ni oxide crystals during high temperature reaction. On the contrary, catalysts prepared by combustion method displayed higher thermal stability following a stability order of: CS-Al1-Zn  >  CS-Al1-Mg  >  CS-Al1-La. Also Fig. 9b shows that Mp selectivity decreased with increasing temperature from 250 to 290 °C. The ability to recover for Mp selectivity of all the combusted catalysts was slightly higher than DEG conversion, indicating a more sensitive nature of the latter than the former to high temperature. Table 1 shows Cu particle size changes of the reduced catalysts before and after reaction at 290 °C for 5 h. Cu in IS-Al1-Zn had the largest particle size, which increased from 30 to 36 nm after 50 h reaction at 290 °C. The continuous and obvious aggregation of Cu particles seriously impeded reactive gases intra-particle flow and led to the deactivation of IS-Al1-Zn catalyst (Fig. 9). On the contrary, Cu particles were highly dispersed in the combusted CS-Al1 catalysts, which did not agglomerate to higher extent during high-temperature reaction due to the presence of promoter metal in CS-Al1 catalysts. Cu particles in CS-Al1-Zn exhibited the smallest particle size and slowest size growth among all catalysts. Relative well-ordered crystalline and smaller particle size will strengthen the synergistic interaction between Cu and ZnO [50], increasing the catalytic activity of the combusted CS-Al1-Zn catalyst. The stability of the most efficient CS-Al1-Zn catalyst for Mp synthesis was measured over 80 h continuous reactions at 230 °C as shown in Fig. 10 . Both DEG conversion and Mp selectivity decreased by less than 2% from initial values demonstrating a highly stable and durable nature of CS-Al1-Zn catalyst. The improved thermal stability of the CS-Al1-Zn could also be credited to high dispersion of Cu as well as Al and Zn oxide species. From Table 1 and Fig. 2, it can be seen that in CS-Al1-Zn, Cu possessed the smallest particle size after being reduced by H2 which counts towards thermal stability under reaction for extended duration and high temperature via decreasing particles agglomeration. Moreover, the generation of Cu-Zn active sites on the Cu surface further leads to nano-crystallites and migration of isolated Cu species during reaction, resulting in higher Mp synthesis by CS-Al1-Zn. Furthermore, the data of DEG conversion and Mp selectivity in this study using Zn-promoted Cu-NiO/Al2O3 was compared with some earlier reports as shown in Table S1 [8,51]. Clearly, Zn-promoted Cu-NiO/Al2O3 catalyst prepared via combustion method possessed higher Mp selectivity than Ni or Cu supported catalysts prepared via impregnation method. The enhanced DEG conversion and high Mp selectivity make the currently designed catalysts as promising candidates for catalytic DEG conversion to Mp. 3.3 GC–MS analysis and reaction mechanism Liquid products were periodically collected from batch reactor and analyzed by GC–MS chromatograph (Agilent 7890A-5975C), having HP-5MS capillary column (30 m in length and 0.25 mm in inner diameter). In Fig. 11 a, seven major peaks were recorded for the product stream. The peaks at 3.3 and 4.1 min were assigned to Mp and DEG, respectively, while that at 3.9 min was assigned to diglycolamine, one of Mp intermediate [51]. The last four peaks with weak intensity at 6.1, 6.2, 6.9 and 8.3 min represented 4-morpholineethanol, morpholinoethylamine, 2-(2-morpholinoethoxy) ethanol and bis (2-morpholinoethyl) ether respectively, which were assumed as the by-products of Mp. From Figs. 8b and 10b, Mp selectivity shows little change with space velocity but dramatically decreased with reaction temperature. Thus, it can be deduced that high temperature was predominantly the controlling factor of Mp transformation in this system rather than contact time. It could be further attributed to the fact that Al acidic sites and Cu species show an increasing activity for DEG conversion but decreasing selectivity for Mp with temperature in the current reaction system. A proposed reaction mechanism is presented in Fig. 11b. Based on the presence of strong peak for Mp and trace amount of DEG (Fig. 11a) in the product stream, it is assumed that DEG was mainly converted to Mp in the presence of NH3 over Zn doped Cu/Ni-Al2O3 catalyst and H2 atmosphere. It involved a two-step mechanism with each step initiating with a nucleophilic attack (ːNH2) on the OH of DEG via dehydration reaction resulting in final diglycolamine molecule [52] (3.9 min, Fig. 11a). In a reducing environment, i.e. H2, diglycolamine via catalytic dehydration reaction results in Mp while regenerating the catalyst (Cu). The resulting Mp in the presence of DEG and some alkyl alcohols (ethanol and ethylene glycol) may undergo further substitution (as seen in Fig. S3) leading to a variety of products i.e. 4-morpholineethanol, morpholinoethylamine, 2-(2-morpholinoethoxy) ethanol and bis(2-morpholinoethyl) ether. 4 Conclusions Combustion method has been proposed to load composite catalysts on Al2O3 support for DEG conversion to Mp. High dispersion and efficient isolation island with Zn promoter enabled the combusted catalysts to exhibit excellent catalytic activity and thermal stability than impregnated catalysts. The reduction peak of Cu in combusted catalysts (CS-Al1-Zn) was up to 40 °C lower than that in the impregnated catalysts (IS-A11-Zn). Thermal stability of Cu/NiO catalysts was significantly improved by the addition of Al/Zn attributed to high dispersion of Cu and inhibiting nano-crystalites aggregation. The optimized CS-Al1-Zn catalyst showed high Mp selectivity (95%) and DEG conversion (99%) under relatively mild reaction conditions i.e. 230 °C, 1.7 MPa H2 pressure and 0.8 mL g−1 h−1 of DEG LHSV. CS-Al1-Zn exhibited excellent thermal stability i.e. <2% decrease in initial DEG to Mp conversion after 80 h reaction. Based on GC–MS analysis of the product stream, proper reaction mechanism was proposed. The current proposed combustion approach could offer competitive alternative to synthesize catalysts for a variety of industrial applications with enhanced activity and thermal stability. coredata.dc:description: Highly active and thermally stable M-Cu-NiO/Al2O3 catalysts (M represents Al/La/Mg/Zn) were prepared by combustion method and applied in diethylene glycol (DEG) conversion to morpholine (Mp). Copper species preserved relatively small crystallite size (19 nm), high dispersion (40.3%) and high surface area (272 m2/g) in M-Cu-NiO/Al2O3 catalysts. High dispersion and intimate contact of copper with Al and La/Mg/Zn synergistically enhanced DEG conversion and Mp selectivity. Addition of promoter i.e. La, Mg, or Zn facilitated the formation of surface defects and isolated species to inhibit migration and aggregation of Cu moities during calcination as well as in high temperature DEG conversion reaction. Compared to other catalysts, Zn-Cu-NiO/Al2O3 combusted catalyst exhibited the highest DEG conversion of 99% (55% higher than impregnated catlayst) and Mp selectivity (95%), even at a high DEG space velocity of 0.8 mL g−1 h−1. Moreover, Zn-Cu-NiO/Al2O3 exhibited excellent thermal stability i.e. less than 2% decrease in initial DEG conversion after 80 h of reaction. The catalysts followed an overall activity order of: Zn-Cu-NiO/Al2O3 > Mg-Cu-NiO/Al2O3  >  La-Cu-NiO/Al2O3. The catalysts were characterized by XRD, BET surface area, SEM and XPS techniques. The present study, credited to its cost-effective nature, simplicity of operation and high efficiency, can be effectively applied for DEG conversion to Mp on industrial level.
coredata.dc:title: Fast catalytic conversion of diethylene glycol to morpholine over thermally stable Zn promoted Cu-NiO/Al2O3 catalyst prepared via combustion approach
